name: Kepler-338
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-338 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-338 is a star with 2.2399999999999993 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.74 times its radius. It is located 1831.99 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-338 is known to have 4 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-338 b

Kepler-338 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.12 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 13.73 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-338.

The mass of Kepler-338 b is 8.21 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-338 b is 2.44 that of Earth. At 8.21 Earth masses, Kepler-338 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-338 c

Kepler-338 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.17 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 24.31 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-338.

The mass of Kepler-338 c is 7.42 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-338 c is 2.34 that of Earth. At 7.42 Earth masses, Kepler-338 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-338 d

Kepler-338 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.26 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 44.43 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-338.

The mass of Kepler-338 d is 13.48 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-338 d is 3 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-338 d is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-338, which contains 4 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
